title: Before 1 January 2018, how many countries, from among Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt, will return their ambassador to Qatar?
preds: I doubt the sotuation will change much in the next week.

@dsarin
Eventful weekend for Saudi Arabia. What if anything do you make of all this (I have no idea what to think): http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2017-11-05/saudi-helicopter-carrying-8-high-ranking-officials-crown-prince-mansour-crashed-all- <-- I think "crown prince" in one of the captions may  be a typo. https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/04/world/middleeast/saudi-arabia-waleed-bin-talal.html OPEC releases embargoed copy of the WTO today and the public version Tuesday. edit2: http://www.reuters.com/article/us-oil-opec-uzbekistan/uzbekistan-to-attend-opec-non-opec-meeting-on-nov-30-saudis-falih-says-idUSKBN1D50HV
edit3: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IV4IjHz2yIo#t=1m16s edit4: http://www.zerohedge.com/news/2017-11-05/did-russias-iranian-energy-deal-kill-four-birds-one-stone <--Where does one acquire such a table?
edit1: @sevedb ... any thoughts on the above?

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/10/analysis-gcc-fate-decided-camp-david-171019085115867.html
This is sort of a cute idea in principle, but there is pretty much nobody who thinks that putting M. Petits-Doigts in a roomful of heads of state and letting him wing it is apt to be helpful.
The countries aren't even talking to each other, much less getting close to resolving the dispute.

The efforts displayed to normalice the situation has only avoid make it worse. Today, there is an even, without a party able to break it. So, Q has been able to deal with its current state, son it seems that it has the capability to hold its position. For the other countries, without some significant concession from Q (for example, closing Al-Jazeera), a return to the previous status quo with empty hands is unbearable.
if, then all. if not, then not one of them. they will try to hold the pressure on Q.
They reopen but financing terror will go on
Following @Anneinak; her data and analysis here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/557980

Based on recent news, Saudi Arabia may be willing to begin talks despite the disputed phone call yesterday. This was the first significant high level contact between Saudi Arabia and Qatar since the split.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-09/qatar-crisis-breakthrough-undermined-by-new-spat-with-saudis The 4 GCC states who broke with Qatar have not been able to recruit others to their cause.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2017/09/07/everyone-is-taking-sides-in-the-qatar-crisis-heres-why-these-four-north-african-states-arent/?utm_term=.8e47d801a7c4 Multiple players want to see more distance between Qatar and Iran.
http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Is-Qatar-trying-to-find-a-way-out-of-the-Gulf-crises-504619 My initial prediction is a slightly better than even odds that Saudi Arabia will return their ambassador by 1-Jan. The others are unlikely to do so with out SA. If SA returns there will be pressure for the others to do the same. The typical reasons regarding Al Jazeera and ties with Iran will remain obstacles but all would benefit from unity. Face saving will be important and this first call is a way to frame future negotiations.

Following, haven't posted a strong take in the question yet. - LH
******************
Executive Director, The Arabia Foundation @arabiafdn علي الشهابي
Ali Shihabi‏Verified account 
@aliShihabi
Emir of Qatar calls  Saudi Crown Prince and expresses interest in dialogue to solve crisis. Saudi CP welcomes this
4:49 PM - 8 Sep 2017
I expect President Trump to inject political leverage in an attempt to break the blockade.  If so, I expect at least one of these countries to re-establish "temporary" ambassadorial relations.

Saudi owns egypt and Bahrain and UAE owns Saudi.  It's definitely all or nothing.  Once Qatar normalized relations with Iran it was pretty much over but so much is kept behind the scenes that it is hard to be 100%.
Nope. Everyone has dug his heals in. Qatar is not going to give in unless there is a change of emir.
Shifting toward none because it looks like no this situation is going to thaw anytime soon. The countries don't even seem to be having serious talks about talks.
Increasing from 95 to 97 for passage of time.

None of the countries will return their ambassadors unless Saudi Arabia does so. So the question is, when will Saudi Arabia restore diplomatic ties and in what terms. As time progresses, its becoming clear that all the Gulf countries are losers in the current standoff with Iran, Turkey and other Gulf rivals as winners. There is a possibility that in 3 months time, both countries will see this situation as unacceptable and come to an acceptable agreement for both parties and restore relationships.

Qatar Restores Full Relations With Iran, Deepening Gulf Feud
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/24/world/middleeast/qatar-iran-boycott-saudi-arabia.html?ribbon-ad-idx=9&rref=world/middleeast

https://www.aei.org/publication/mirage-or-oasis-tensions-ease-between-bitter-gulf-rivals/ "Initially, the anti-Qatar Quartet hoped for a quick surrender by Qatar. Now, that’s off the table, and all the regional states are settling in for the long-haul. Saudi Arabia, the UAE, Bahrain, and Egypt are not going to back down because they figure they’ve already given Qatar a chance, after the 2014 mini-crisis [dispute over Qatar’s support for the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt], but that it did not fulfill its agreements to resolve that dry-run for the current crisis. What’s happening now is a prolonged cold war, albeit one that won’t get in the way of other regional states to conduct business as usual, even if they’re on opposite sides of the Qatar issue. That doesn’t mean a resolution is at hand because, God knows, there’s a huge difference between “business as usual” and peace when it comes to the Middle East.

After Qatar announced recently that it is re-establishing diplomatic contact with Iran, I doubt that this is going to happen, but if it does, I think it would include only 3 of them--not Egypt.   Thanks to @Rene & @Gibson, I just learned that Egypt never returned its ambassador after  the last diplomatic tit-for-tat.

https://www.rferl.org/a/qatar-restores-full-diplomatic-relations-iran-slap-saudi-arabia-arab-coalition/28693870.html
With reporting by AP, Reuters, AFP, Al-Jazeera, and Interfax Qatar announced on August 24th that  its ambassador will return to Tehran "to resume his diplomatic duties," without specifying an exact date for the ambassador's return or providing his name.. . . The decision defies demands by Saudi Arabia and several Arab allies that Doha sever remaining ties with Tehran.   Later in the day, Iran said it welcomed this decision. "The development of relations with our neighbors is an absolute priority" for Tehran, Qasemi [an Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman] added. Qatar recalled its ambassador to Iran in January last year after Saudi Arabia cut ties with the Islamic republic, accusing Tehran of failing to protect its embassy in the capital and consulate in Mashhad against protesters who had ransacked them. The protests followed Saudi Arabia's execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a prominent Shi'ite cleric in the kingdom who had rallied antigovernment protests.. . .  "Iran has shown its support to Qatar, in particular by sending food shipments to Qatar and by allowing Qatar's national carrier to use its airspace. "Also on August 24, Zarif, the Iranian foreign minister, was quoted as saying that Iran and Saudi Arabia will exchange diplomatic visits soon. He told the semiofficial ISNA news agency that the visit could take place after the hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia ends in the first week of September. "Visas have been delivered for the two sides," Zarif said. "The final steps need to be completed so our diplomats can go inspect our embassy and consulate in Saudi Arabia and for Saudi diplomats to come inspect their embassy and consulate." "An agreement between Tehran and Riyadh earlier this year will allow Iranian citizens to take part in this year's hajj. Iranians were largely absent from the pilgrimage last year following a 2015 crowd stampede that killed hundreds of Iranian worshippers.

In 2002, Saudi Arabia broke off diplomatic ties with Qatar, which were restored in 2008. In 2014, diplomatic ties were broken off again, for 8 months. A faster resolution this time, especially with the kind of demands Saudis have made, will be difficult.  In 2014, Iran, Qatar's other big neighbour, was under oppressive sanctions - many of which are now gone, and it helped Qatar with food shipments. Turkey has also acted in favour of Qatar. So Qatar seems to be in a stronger position, and may be less willing to agree to the Saudi ultimatum wholesale.  The UAE may be willing to break ranks with the Saudi alliance - it is rich and doesn't rely on Saudi aid. Bahrain is a client state that relied on Saudi troops to put down popular protests. Egypt is a recipient of Saudi aid, so these two are less likely to break ranks with Saudi. In their case, ties will be restored for all of them together, or not at all.

There's this: https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/aug/17/saudi-arabia-open-border-qatar-pilgrims-attend-hajj But as the article says, Quote: Some observers cautioned on Thursday that the diplomatic crisis was far from over despite the border decision. “This is a goodwill gesture towards the Qatari people and not a breakthrough with the Qatari government,” tweeted Ali Shihabi from the Washington-based thinktank Arabia Foundation. End quote. I'm sticking with zero for now, but given the turn-on-a-dime alignments of the Middle East, who knows?
Due to the slight easing of restrictions, these ambassadors return is looking more likely. I think this would be a all-or-nothing situation if this occurs.

Qatar will take some steps to distance itself from the Muslim Brotherhood and Iran and the four Sunni Nation's, being pragmatic about relations with a wealthy neighbor, will return their ambassadors. The USA, having an interest in Qatar's base, will help to facilitate a rapprochement.

King Abdullah can't help this time:
http://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-ambassadors-of-gulf-arab-states-to-return-to-qatar-2014nov16-story.html
Good information @chigginson. Makes sense that digging in will continue and we're talking just 5 months.
The current demands are unlikely to be met by Qatar, this could drag on without resolution for some time.

As of today, 7/30, the four countries still appear unified on punishing Qatar: 
http://www.statesman.com/news/arab-states-open-dialogue-with-qatar-demands-are-met/eOuxsB1n8CU3ZKLHXDW3sK/ Even if Qatar wanted to comply with the list, it would take longer than six months:
1) Shut down or move a major international newspaper.
2) Close a Turkish airbase that has been in the works since a 2002 military agreement.  Turkey has been quick to come to Qatar's defense during this last few weeks.
3) Treat a current ally as an enemy and prove it ( Iran ).  Iran is also perhaps it's biggest economic ally simply by geography: http://www.haaretz.com/middle-east-news/1.793798
4) Turn over individuals who may have fled to Qatar because of their political or religious affiliations.  I am sure this needs to go through identification process and Qatari courts.
5) Payment of reparations for victims of terrorism given shelter or funds by Qatar.    Qatar has funded so many terrorist organisations this would be similar to identifying all victims of the tobacco industry and beginning prosecution in six months. I'm leaving a three percent chance that serious discussions start and ambassadors return. However,  I think there is a zero percent chance they will return because demands met. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_Qatar_diplomatic_crisis

Even it's low probability, one is possible, two would be an agreement, 3 is almost impossible, the 4th left would do as others, so 4 is more probable than 3.
Egypt is the most probable country to act so.

Even if relations improve, a return of an ambassador is a fairly formal step that will likely take some significant amount of time. The withdrawal of ambassadors in fact occurred already in 
2014 before the current rise in tensions. Reinstatement seems very unlikely so soon.  On the other hand, if one reinstatement occurs, we might get all 4 of them quickly.
what I heard on Charlie Rose last night.

"Qatar could declare legally stop gas exports to UAE: QP"
This will escalate the crisis really quickly. I see power outages in UAE. Panic on the streets, no air con...

Qatar turns down new LNG deals with Egypt - traders
http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/qatar-turns-down-new-lng-deals-with-egypt-traders/articleshow/59776066.cms
Crisis? What crisis?

Secretary of State Tillerson seems to care about resolving the crisis (though I don't know how much the ambassador piece of it matters to him). He probably knows the players from his time at Exxon, so it should be in his wheelhouse. I don't see why he wouldn't be good at getting to a resolution. Egypt seems to have somewhat different incentives/allegiances than the other three states so I could see it moving alone, or the other three countries moving together, or all four moving together. See http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2017/07/tillerson-call-saudi-arabic-lift-blockade-qatar-oman.html
https://editorials.voa.gov/a/agreement-with-qatar/3943143.html
https://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2017/07/272522.htm
https://www.state.gov/secretary/remarks/2017/06/272103.htm
One might have an acute reason to do so, but otherwise they're in no hurry
I think it will happen and it will be all or none but I am not sure how fast it will happen.

One of these countries (EGY) is more susceptible to the reality of economics  and if pressured may relent. The others can afford for this to go on in the medium term, much will depend on other factors such as the ongoing campaign in Yemen.

I think this is an all or nothing thing. I also think the Qatar situation is more likely to become a frozen conflict like some many others in the region (looking at you Saudi Arabia-Iran and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict) than to be resolved anytime soon.

From news reports, Qatar is opening to Iran, which would probably preclude any kind of reconciliation with the Sunni powers in the next few months. On the other hand, alignments in the Middle east can turn on a dime, so the matter bears watching. But for now, no chance.
This will be a bloc move one way or the other.  All four in or all 4 out.  Before the year ends there will be enough pressure to find a face saving compromise allowing  a return to normal.
I would that Egypt and Bahrain and the UAE and Saudi Arabia form 2 distinct blocks of 2. Either both blocks, 1 block or 0 blocks will forgive Quatar.

We'll see how mediation efforts go, but even if the U.S. and Kuwait have some success, it's unlikely it'll return to a normal diplomatic relationship. While the 4 countries seem to be pretty unified, I'm not sure they'll follow UAE's lead on taking a completely hard-line stance.
its all 4 or none, as this is all coordinated.  Doesn't look likely, even assuming other powers try to assist.

After all the vitriol directed at Qatar from these four countries, UAE and Saudi Arabia in particular, I can't envisage their Ambassadors coming back any time this year.  However, with nearly six months left, I'm not going to 100% just yet.
